sections.title: Understand the assignment
sections.description: It is always worth spending some time considering carefully what you have been asked to do and making sure that you understand what is expected.  Understanding the essay brief explains some key terms.  See also Assignment Types for other forms of academic writing.

sections.title: Generate ideas
sections.description: Take a look at visual thinking and planning for some ideas about brainstorming

sections.title: Make a research plan
sections.description: Take a look at planning and organising research.  You might also want to consult the librarys study support pages.  And you might want to think about organisation and time management

sections.title: Locate sources
sections.description: Begin with your reading lists and lecture notes. See also the Study Support pages from the Library

sections.title: Review sources
sections.description: It is worth spending some time reviewing the sources (books, journals, websites etc) you have found and deciding which will be most useful to you.  You should also consider whether they count as reliable academic sources.

sections.title: Reading and notemaking
sections.description: Have you thought about your reading strategies? And how useful do you find your notes? The links below on reading and note making have some useful ideas.

sections.title: Revisit and update original plan
sections.description: Now is a good time to take a look at where your research has taken you.  You will probably find that your original ideas have developed and possibly changed so its worth spending some time taking stock and updating the plan

sections.title: Collate your notes
sections.description: Now is the time to get together all your notes and organise them. Can you identify any themes and categories that would be useful for grouping the notes together? These themes and categories could later become sections of your essay. See the next steps for more info on how to do this.

sections.title: Arrange your notes to reflect a possible argument
sections.description: For this crucial step you might find this synthesis matrix useful.  Your argument should be the thread that leads your reader through your writing and will give the writing shape and purpose.  For help see finding your argument and also using sources and adopting a critical perspective

sections.title: Make a writing plan
sections.description: It is very difficult to structure your material successfully without writing a plan.  You need to remember to shape the writing so it has purpose and direction (look at previous section) Arrange your notes to reflect a possible argument.

sections.title: Start your first draft
sections.description: Your writing plan should give you a framework to work with (but you might need to adjust it as your work develops). Remember to adopt a critical perspective and develop your points using (evidence and) sources.

sections.title: Follow up additional research
sections.description: Go back to your research and find sources to fill in gaps/points that need evidence.

sections.title: Revise and rewrite
sections.description: Revise and redraft your work, ensuring that your argument is clearly identifiable and your material is well structured. Write your introduction and conclusion.

sections.title: Complete referencing
sections.description: Remember to check which referencing system you should be using and be consistent throughout your assignment. You can use the referencing guides for help.

links.title: Referencing styles by course (Falmouth and Exeter)

sections.title: Speak to a writing advisor
sections.description: Book an appointment with an ASK writing advisor.

sections.title: Check argument
sections.description: Look over your work and check that your key argument is clearly presented and explained with evidence,revising and redraftingif necessary. Yourintroduction and conclusionshould introduce/summarise your key points.

sections.title: Check formatting
sections.description: Make sure that your assignment is formatted as specified in your assignment brief/as requested by your tutor and that the same font, quotation style etc is used throughout. See Layout for essays and dissertations.

sections.title: Check references
sections.description: Look over your references and bibliography to ensure that they are all correct and up to date to avoid plagiarism.

links.title: Referencing styles by course (Falmouth and Exeter)
